p: Since their discovery in the early twentieth century, lytic bacteriophages have been seen to have promising potential as antimicrobial agents, although this potential was broadly surpassed by the rapid development of antibiotics as our main antibacterial agents. Currently, the applications of lytic bacteriophages go far beyond their antimicrobial activity as they are now engineered as vehicles for drug delivery and vaccines [ 68, 69] and broadly used in molecular biology and microbiology [ 70, 71].
